content: How can I help you today?
I’ve been struggling with sleep lately. My mind just doesn’t stop racing at night. I feel like all this stress from work and worrying about providing for my family is just keeping me awake.

It sounds like balancing work, family, and stress has been really heavy on your mind, especially at night when you're trying to rest. It can be so frustrating to feel like you can't turn your thoughts off when you just want sleep. How are you handling that stress during the day?

During the day, I just try to power through. I focus on my work and keep pushing myself, but I feel like it always catches up with me when I'm lying in bed. It’s like everything I’m trying to block out just rushes in all at once.

It really sounds like you’ve been carrying a lot during the day, putting your energy into pushing through and staying focused, but then at night, it’s all catching up and overwhelming you. That must leave you feeling drained and frustrated. What do you think might help you create more space to process that stress—or even just ease into sleep more peacefully?

Honestly, I don’t know what would help. I’ve tried using my phone to distract myself from the thoughts, but it just makes things worse. I feel like I’m stuck in this cycle, and I don’t know how to break it.

It sounds like you’ve been trying different ways to cope, but they haven’t given you the peace you’re looking for. Being stuck in a cycle like that can feel exhausting and discouraging. What is important to you when it comes to feeling calmer or more in control of your nights?

I guess what’s important to me is just being able to quiet my mind so I can actually recharge at night. I want to wake up feeling ready to face the day instead of already worn out. I feel like if I could just figure that part out, maybe I’d handle everything else a little better.

You want to be able to quiet your mind and feel refreshed when you wake up, ready to take on the day. It sounds like gaining that kind of rest is really meaningful for you—not just for sleep, but to help you tackle everything else with more energy and balance. What do you think has been standing in the way of that lately?

It’s definitely my thoughts about work and not being able to provide for my family. I just keep overthinking every little thing—whether I’m doing enough at work, how I’d handle things if something went wrong, how it impacts my family. Then it spirals, and I don’t know how to stop it.

It sounds like those thoughts about work and providing for your family weigh heavily on you, and they keep building up until they feel like too much to handle. It’s understandable that thinking about such important responsibilities would feel overwhelming. What would it look like for you if those thoughts didn’t spiral as much? How might that change things for you?

I guess if those thoughts didn’t spiral so much, I’d actually feel some peace. Maybe I could get through the night without feeling like I’m drowning in everything. It would probably help me be more present with my family and even a little more confident at work.

Feeling some peace at night would mean so much, wouldn’t it? You’re imagining a calmer you—someone who can rest, wake up refreshed, and be more present and confident in the things that matter most. That sounds like something really worth holding onto. What do you think could be a small step toward making that calmer space for yourself?
I’m not sure, honestly. Maybe I could try putting my phone down earlier. But even when I’ve tried that, I just end up lying there and the thoughts still come. I don’t know what else could help.

It sounds like you’re willing to try things, like putting your phone down earlier, even if it hasn’t worked the way you hoped. That shows you’re open to making changes, which is a strength you already have. It might take a little experimenting to figure out what works for you. What other ideas, even small ones, have crossed your mind that might be worth exploring?

Maybe starting some sort of routine before bed could help, like writing down my thoughts or trying to relax with some deep breathing or something like that. I haven’t done anything like that before, but I’m guessing it could be worth a shot. I just don’t know if it will actually help.

That’s a thoughtful idea—creating a bedtime routine, like writing down your thoughts or trying relaxation techniques, sounds like it might give you a chance to clear your mind or calm down before sleep. It’s understandable to feel unsure about whether it will help, but it’s a positive step toward even giving yourself that space to unwind. How would you feel about trying one of those ideas?

I think I could give it a shot. Maybe starting with writing down my thoughts before bed could help me get some of the stress out of my head. I’m not sure if it will make a big difference, but I guess it’s better than staying stuck in this cycle.

That sounds like a great step to try—writing down your thoughts could be a way to release some of the stress that’s been building up. Even if it’s not a big overnight change, it’s a way of giving yourself a chance to approach things differently and maybe start breaking out of that cycle. Is there anything else you’d like to talk about or explore related to your sleep or stress before moving on to planning more concretely?
I think I’m okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
